page.lettertext:
fol.161r
Right honorable, and my singular good Lord, having
lost
M
r
Secretary Walsingham
, whome I can not
name unto yo
w
, w
t
any moderat grief, I beseeche
yo
r
L. to hold me excused, that I putte yo
w
to
some troble in this addresse of my letters. for
although I am not ignorant, that yo
r
L. should be
spared in suche respectes, yet because I under-
stand not as yet, whome her
Ma
tie
hath appointed
to exercise
at office, and because
e mater wherof
I purpose to informe, is of speciall qualitie and
weight, I trust yo
r
L. will passe it with a fa-
vorable acceptation. I doe not dout
but yo
r
L. hath
heeretofore
bin made acquainted,
w
t
that whiche I have signified home
,
my former informations
about
e towne
of
Groninghen.
It was an assured persuasion
of divers gentlemen of
Friseland,
Emden,
and
other places, who writte unto me about it, that
the inhabitants of that towne were so weary of
e
Spaniard, and so well affected to her Ma
tie
that
if those good meanes were used, w
ch
her Hig
nes
w
t
a smalle charge might put in execution, they
would be easely drawen to submit themselves
unto her: Alwaies provided that they might not
any way be subject to
e states of these contreis.
I
Having
[.]
certified
hereof, w
at
home
w
t
suche other
informac
o
ns I recea-
ved,
for
e
ties
to w
ch
whereto
M
r
Secretary
set this
made no
answear [.]
u
to me That her
Ma
tie
by reason of her excessive charges otherwise,
would not enter into a further expense, by sending
over ether mony, or forces: but if by using her
name, autoritie and countenance, they could finde
the meanes to w
t
stand, or annoy
e Enemie, I should
give to them of
e towne, what encouragement I
could. The effect of this answear I imparted
fol.161v
presently to those from whom the motion first pro-
ceeded, who signified againe, that there was no hope
of any good to be done, unles her Ma
tie
would vouche-
safe to send her letters to
e towne, w
t
and
promise to
maintene bothe them and their liberties against
their Enemies
and
and
cause to be presented suche fur-
ther assistance and succo
rs
before
e towne, as ha-
ving revolted, they
may
might
be able assuredly to make
it good against
e Enemie. Finding her Ma
tie
thus unwilling to take
e enterprise in hand, in
respect of
e charge, and in those of Groninghen no
maner of inclination to deale w
t
e states; consi-
dering also that if her Hig
nes
should attempt any
thing in these quarters, w
t
out
e privitie of the
states, it would be both hardly perfourmed and
give a great occasion of suspicion
among them
to [.] ill [.]
I knowe no better course for e contentac
o
n of all
parties, then to acquaint
e
Councel of state
w
t
the whole mater: whiche I did accordingly.
For I declared heere
in Councel
[.]
, what offers were made
unto her Ma
tie
, for w
at
cause she refused them, howe
willing she was, that
e contrey should take the
benefit of using her autoritie, what letters had bin
written unto me from sundrie places and persons,
and w
at
answears I had returned.
Among
others I shewed
at letter, wherof I send
e copie
heerew
t
, whiche by
e advise of certaine gentlemen
of Emden, I writte to
e Magistrats and commons
of Groninghen.
In effect I made as many cir-
cumstances knowen unto them, as might induce
them to advise, howe to reape
e fruite of
a
t
that
over-
ture. Wheruppon it was resolved that I should
persist in writing to those of Emden, and take as
perfit informac
o
n, as I could, of
e nombers of
fol.162r
those that were well affected in Groninghen,
of
e meanes w
ch
they had to compasse their purpose,
w
t
suche
necessarie
pointes,
besides
as
e enterprise required.
And this I perfourmed to their satisfaction
alwaies shewing those letters w
ch
I writte and re-
ceaved. Moreoever to
e end I might
e better
stand assured of
e true estate of all thinges, I
sent this bearer
Christopher Persival
to Emden,
who, of a special devotion to
e service, adventured
uppon his owne charge, and not w
t
out great dan-
ger, to approche w
t
in half a mile of
e towne,
and
where he taried certaine daies in a village, and
found
e meanes to c
o
ferre w
t
divers of
e Bur-
ghers,
w
ch
who
resorted unto him at several times,
and
thereby understood
,
gave h
i
good i[.] of
e disposition of
e Commons,
w
t
suche other particularities as he himself will
declare. For w
ch
good service I have put him
heer
in
some
hope,
at by yo
r
honorable
L.
meanes he shalbe
s
o
wat considered./. In one of my letters, w
ch
I writte to
those of emden I had signified,
at we had cer-
taine intelligence by letters newly intercepted,
that
e
D. of Parma
was resolutly bent, by one
meanes or other, to place a Garrison in
e towne
Groningh
e
of Groninghen
, and to that purpose had charged
Verdugo
e Governo
r
there, to take
e very first
and spediest opportunitie. This letter of mine
was sent by those of Emden into Groninghen, up=
pon
e sight wherof
e people caused all
e Spa-
niardes and Fributters in
e towne,
being
to
the nomber of 210
& more
to
depart
avoid
presently, and
ordered w
t
all that Verdugo himself should not
come neere any port in
e night time. Not
to troble yo
r
L. w
t
a
needeles
tedios
rehersal of all that
hath passed, the Councel of state, and likewise
fol.162v
Count William
e Governo
r
of Friseland, who hath
also conferred both w
t
them and w
t
me in this
mater, doe apparantly finde that
e interposition
of her Ma
ties
autoritie, may
very
easely allure the towne
to unite it self w
t
these Provinces. And seing her
Ma
tie
, to whome they should seeme to be only ad-
dicted, will not deale for her self, not those of
e
towne be persauded to
seeke
yeld
unto
e states, from
whome they have revolted, it is thought there is no
readier way to atchieve
e enterprise w
t
a gene-
ral good liking, then to entreat her Ma
tie
to signe to
that letter, or
e like in substance, as I have sent
heerew
t
to yo
r
L. w
ch
is written in
e Flemmish
tongue, by
e advise of
e Councel, because fewe
in Groninghen understand
e Frenche, and
that
e
it is
[.]
t
e
common people
may
shold
understand it
e better
How-
beit
I have sent
e translation w
t
it, and likewise
a letter from
e Councell to her Hig
nes
and an other
from Count William.
Moreover
There is mention made in
this
the
letter, w
ch
is desired to be signed by her Ma
tie
of a
former letter w
ch
I
was
writt
e
unto
e
towne
,
Magistrats [.]
being
e
same, as I signified before, and
co
m
ons of the towne
wherof I
have sent the transcript
Wherto I was
adv
r
tised by my
My frindes of
E
d
e
did advise
me unto it
and
W
ch
Yt
is thought very necessary
to be sent againe
that the copie
therof shold be sent [inclosed] in her Ma
ties
letter because it is given out by divers in
e towne, that
it was nether my letter, nor written by her Ma
ties
order, but a devise of Count William, or of
e states:
wheras nowe inclosed in her Ma
ties
letter, it will both
ratifie
at, and o
r
other proceedinges. It is
intended also,
at when
e letter to be signed by her
Hig
nes
shallbe returned,
S
r
Francis Vere
being
lieng
at
Disbourgh,
w
ch
is
w
t
in one daies jorney of Groninghen,
shall joine his forces w
t
Count Williams, who are
able both together to raise to
e nomber of 3000
wheras
e Enemie in those quarters is not above 2000
fol.163r
and shall present themselves before
e towne, and
send
e said letter by a drumme or trompet.
Wheruppon it is conceaved,
at if her Ma
ties
frindes
be
e greater nomber, they will presently come to
capitulat: or if
ei be
e weaker part, yet fin-
ding assistance w
t
out, they will happely be able
to deliver a port, or give some other entrie unto
them. Howsoever it succeed,
e attempt hath
nether charge nor daunger,
but
a
d
in all probablitie
will endommage
e Enemie exceedingly. More-
over to animat those of
e towne, I have put
them in hope,
at her Ma
tie
may be wonne in time
to drawe
e trade of her marchants Adventu-
rers thither, whereunto they seeme to listen very
gladly. I can not
also
omitte to make it knowen
to yo
r
L. that Count William doth persuade
himself, that if
e enterprise take place, her
Ma
tie
will be pleased to commit
e place to
his government.
A
d
were it otherwise, I doe as-
sure my self
at nether he, nor
e
states of Frise
,
would intermeddle in
e Action.
And to
To
[.]
deliver
my [.] opinion
to yo
r
L.
considering his sufficiencie,
whereto
against w
ch
there is no exception,
and
e
good
[.]
meanes that he hath, to assist
e towne,
as
neede shall require, w
t
succo
rs
out of Frise-
land, besides
e right w
ch
he pretendeth to
e
Government, as being a parcel of that whiche
he hath in Frise, I can not conceave howe any
other person, can better fitte w
t
e people, or
the place.
I have [.]
to yo
r
L.

will be yelded

ch

Thus in general termes I have

unto yo

a dessiegne of suche moment,
as
yo
r

it may please

ch
I am humbly to be-

w
, to
a
d

tie
procuring
withall
unto it
suche dispatche of answear, as yo
r
L.

wisdome shall judge convenient.
And so I take
my humble leave. From
e Hage. A
